pages.text: $(#2F892F)$(l)【Messenger of the Wind】$()$(br2)“At dawn, when the first rays of sunlight pierce the clouds, their pappus points towards the nearest water source.”$(br2)This seemingly unremarkable member of the Asteraceae family boasts emerald-green, serrated basal leaves. Its golden composite flowers later transform into delicate seed spheres. Each parachute-like seed is an aerodynamic marvel—capable of drifting over 128 blocks. Adventurers often observe the flower’s opening and closing patterns to predict upcoming weather changes.
A master of adaptation, dandelions grow in nearly every biome, save for the most extreme environments. As long as there is soil and sunlight, its seeds will find their way.

Excerpt from *Desert Wayfarers' Ballads*$(br)The old caravan master, Hassan, always tied a dandelion puff to his camel’s bell.$(br)When sandstorms swallowed the trade routes, he would pluck a single tuft and cast it skyward—$(br)And those drifting seeds,$(br)Would shimmer like guiding stars,$(br)Tracing the path to the oasis.$(br)Remember, child, there are no useless lives in the desert. Each floating seed is a love letter from the earth to the sky.

This golden-green infusion is brewed from dandelion petals and morning dew, carrying a sun-kissed, grassy aroma. Nomadic tribes call it ‘The Breath of the Earth,’ for upon drinking, one can almost hear the whisper of the wind sweeping through the plains.$(br2)$(#2F892F)But beware—legend has it that if you drink three cups in quick succession, tiny dandelions may begin to sprout from your hair, only withering upon the next full moon...$()
